statement.tex:
%text Solve this Linear Programming problem graphically. Maximise $Z=-x+2y$ subject to the following four constraints: %
\begin{tabular}{ll} x \ge 3 &x+y \ge 5 \\ x+2y\ge 6 & y \ge 0 \end{tabular} \\

reason.tex:
%text The plot that correctly represent the feasible region given the constraints is %
x+y\ge 5\implies y\ge -x+5 \\ \text{(area above $y=-x+5$)}\\ x+2y\ge 6\implies y\ge -x/2+3 \\ \text{(area above $y=-x/2+3$)}

options.tex: \begin{align} \text{Corner Points}\qquad &Z=-x+2y \\ (3, 2) \qquad &1 \\ (4, 1) \qquad &-2 \\ (6, 0) \qquad &-6 \end{align}\\ \text{cannot predict maximum based on}\\ \text{this information.}

reason.tex: %text Feasible region is unbounded (open), therefore we cannot predict the maximum based on corner points alone. %

%text The open half plane $-x+2y\gt 1$ will determine if a maximum is possible. % -x+2y\gt 1\implies y\gt x/2+1/2 \\ \text{i.e. above line }-x+2y\gt 1 \\
%text The open half plane does have points in common with the feasible region, therefore no maximum is possible! %
